Situation1: They are expected to be present at a family dinner or small gathering.
Expectation2: Meet sales targets set by management
Situation2: Midway through the week, their individual sales numbers are already on pace to surpass the quota.
Story: I stared at my phone, the screen lighting up with my manager’s reminder: “Push for just a few more sales tonight, and you’ll break the weekly record!” My heart thudded with a mix of pride and anxiety. I was so close—just a handful of calls away from not only meeting but exceeding my quota. But then my sister’s message popped up, a photo of the dinner table set for our family gathering. “Don’t be late! Mom made your favorite,” she wrote, adding a string of heart emojis. I could almost smell the food, hear the laughter, feel the warmth of being together. But the clock was ticking, and every minute spent at dinner was a minute lost from calling potential customers. My family expected me to be present, to share stories and laughter, to be a good sister. My job demanded I keep dialing, keep selling, keep pushing. I felt the weight of both worlds pressing in, my phone heavy in my hand, torn between the promise of professional success and the pull of family belonging.
